text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with easy Peking duck lettuce cups
that's right don't let the quotation
marks Puglia even though we're going to
use different ingredients different
technique and a different presentation
the flavors here are similar the results
incredibly delicious and not to mention
this is significantly easier real Peking
duck takes a lot of work including
believe it or not blowing air under the
skin but there's no need to do any of
that here in fact the only thing you're
going to blow is your chances of not
getting lots of compliments so let's go
ahead and get started with our duck legs
and I have six of them right here
and unlike duck breasts or even whole
duck the legs are relatively affordable
and I think a great value because they
really are pretty much all meat but
anyway let's go ahead and prep these for
the oven which is an extremely fast and
easy process so what we'll do first is
drizzle over a little bit of vegetable
oil followed by a fairly generous amount
of kosher salt and that may look like a
lot but it's not we really do need that
much here and then besides the salt we
will also add some freshly ground black
pepper as well as our not so secret
ingredient Chinese five-spice which if
you're not exactly clear what that is
I'll go into a little bit of detail on
the blog one spoiler though there's
often more than five spices I know that
does sound mathematically impossible but
it's not and then we'll take our tongs
and we will mix those extremely
thoroughly and by the way tongs are a
terrible tool for this job if I was not
filming I would have one maybe two hands
in there to mix these up but anyway one
way or another we will get those duck
legs coated with our spices at which
point we can set those aside and move on
to prep our baking dish and for that all
we're going to do is take some green
onions and cut them in large pieces and
scatter those on the bottom and then
we'll go ahead and place our duck legs
right over the top skin side up and once
our duck legs have been placed in as
evenly as possible I'm going to scatter
about four or five garlic cloves that
have been cut in half
and by the way there's no need to take
the paper off of these just cut them in
half and place them in and around the
duck and believe it or not that's it I
wasn't kidding when I said this was easy
and then we'll go ahead and wrap this
for the oven which means I'm going to
put one piece of parchment paper over
the top of the duck and I just feel like
that keeps the moisture and the flavor
sort of closer to the duck yet again
another theory I can't prove but I'm
pretty sure is correct
and then let's go ahead and cover the
entire thing tightly with foil like very
tightly at which point we're going to
transfer this into the center of a 250
degree oven for 3 hours so we're
definitely going to go low and slow here
and once our duck legs have cooked for 3
hours what I want you to do is turn off
the oven crack it open and just let that
pan sit in there for another hour
don't peek don't take off the foil just
let it sit there and then what we'll do
after the hour is pull it out of the
oven and let it continue cooling to room
temp before we attempt to put this in
the fridge and if everything's gone
according to plan it should look
something like this and fair warning it
will smell amazing and if you have to
you can use these now but I highly
recommend you don't I really do think
this recipe should be started a day
before you want to eat it because what
I'm going to suggest is give these a
little basting with the fat and assuming
this is cooled down to room temp what
we'll do is rewrap it and place it in
the fridge overnight and not only do I
think that's going to give this a better
texture but a better flavor as well so
I'm going to pop mine in the fridge and
use it the next day
and since we have to wait let's go ahead
and make the sauce which in this case
for me is going to be sort of a
tricked-out hoisin sauce so in a mixing
bowl I have some hoisin too which I'm
going to add a nice splash of sesame oil
and you want to be careful not too much
that isn't ingredient that can overpower
things and then I'm also going to give
it a little splash of hot sauce and then
for some acidity to help balance the
fatty duct I'm going to do the juice of
half a lemon and once that's in I'm just
going to give this a mix and that super
simple sauce is done ensure just plain
plum sauce or hoisin sauce is more
traditional but I really do think you're
going to enjoy this little variation so
we will mix that up and set it aside and
then we'll fast forward to the next day
and pull out our duck which after a
night in the fridge should look like
this and you can see we have a
significant amount of fat which you will
be saving for sure because that's
definitely the stuff you want to use to
crisp up your duck as you'll find out is
the fat with the F that makes this fat
with a pea and if we want we could cook
these duck legs whole but I'm making
lettuce cups so what we're going to do
is remove the bones and cut this into
like half-inch pieces and a duck leg is
going to have like two main bones plus
you also have this little skinny one as
well as the hip joint
but other than that that's pretty much a
solid piece of delicious succulent meat
and I'm sure you would have done it even
if I didn't tell you but we definitely
want to pick off any meat still attached
to those bones we pulled out and as far
as our nice big pieces go all we're
going to do is cube it up using our
standard of food wishes cubing system
and all that means is to cut it into
strips and then we'll turn those strips
and cut them across into approximately
half inch pieces and please note we did
not remove the skin here not only is
that going to be tasty and get crispy I
believe it's also very good for you I
think I wrote that somewhere but that is
up to you you are the Fat Boy slim of
what to do to your skin but I will go on
the record as saying if you take it off
you're crazy and once our duck has been
cut up we can head over to the stove to
cook this up and generally the way I do
this is to melt some of that duck fat in
a pan over medium-high heat
toss in my duck chunks and simply cook
stirring until they're heated through
and the skin starts to crisp up a little
bit except that's not what I did this
time I tried a little bit of an
experiment that I think worked out
pretty well I decided to cook this meat
extremely crispy borderline crunchy and
then toss in some more duck meat that
would just barely be heated through so I
would have a combination of crispy
crunchy meat along with meat that was
moister and softer so as soon as my
second addition of duck was heated
through I finished this with some salt
yes you will need to season this and I
also tossed in a few more green onions
and stirred that together at which point
we are ready to fill some lettuce
traditional Peking duck is served with
crepes or pancakes or little buns but
since none of us are allowed to eat
carbs anymore I won with the lettuce and
then of course will top it with some of
our tricked-out hoisin sauce and then
for a little crunch and a little subtle
bitterness I'm going to do a little bit
of diced cucumber as well as a little
bit of chopped green onion I also
decided to shake over some toasted
sesame seeds for a little bit of
additional nuttiness although
technically I guess it would be a little
bit of seediness
but you know what I mean and then last
but not least because it was sitting on
my cutting board for a different recipe
I decided to garnish with a thin slice
of fresh cayenne pepper and those easy
King duck lettuce cups are done and
looking incredibly enticing so let me go
ahead and grab that leaf and use that to
help me get this into my mouth and that
was just way beyond delicious I mean
just insanely tasty and I've had real
Peking duck countless times and while
it's not a really fair comparison I
thought this was every bit as good
whoops I lost couple the best pieces now
what am I gonna do okay that works but
anyway the combination of that crispy
and succulent duck those aromatic spices
that sweet and savory sauce just all
comes together to make something
extraordinary I'm serious I could eat 10
of these they really are that addictive
it's like quack so I really do hope you
give these a try head over to food
wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
